Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Integrated Approach to Measuring Dynamic Economic Resilience Following Disasters

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2011, the nation experienced a record fourteen, billion-dollar weather-related disasters. The next year, Superstorm Sandy, the focus of this study, caused an estimated $68 billion in losses, making it the second-costliest storm in our history. These losses show why it is critical to understand how the nation can become more resilient in the face of disasters. Dynamic resilience, defined in this project as the ability to "bounce back" after experiencing a disaster, is widely seen as a way of reducing the disruption disasters cause and of containing costs, including those borne by individual property owners, the U. S. Treasury in the form of disaster aid, and the insurance/reinsurance sector. The financial losses that result from disasters and post-disaster recovery assistance reduce the supply of resources available for other productive investment. This project is thus consistent with the mission of NSF, particularly aspects of that focus on understanding how to "advance national health, prosperity, and welfare."

In this study, we will explore one dimension of resilience - dynamic economic resilience - by developing a better understanding of how affected businesses in the New York City area coped following Sandy and the extent to which they were able to recover. We seek to understand in an integrated way how both business owners' decisions and broader economic conditions contribute to resilience. We will model post-disaster recovery investment decisions; conduct a survey with a representative sample of businesses to learn more about their recovery decision making; and examine the effects of community-level conditions such as employment rates, labor force characteristics, and community economic diversity on dimensions of economic resilience and recovery. The project will employ several analytic strategies to provide a holistic and integrated model that incorporates micro-, miso-, and macro-level factors affecting economic resilience following disasters. A microeconomic investment framework will be developed to take into account business owners' decisions to invest in post-disaster recovery. A database will be developed consisting of community-level factors important for regional economic recovery. We will also develop a dynamic computable general disequilibrium model to analyze resilience at the macroeconomic level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1.  Development of a conceptual framework for the study of dynamic economic resilience at both the micro and macro levels.  At the micro level the framework distinguishes between investment for the purposes of: restoration/replacement/repair/reconstruction of previous productive capacity, expansion of productive capacity, productivity enhancement, and vulnerability reduction (in relation to future disasters).

2.  Identification of four key metrics relating to post-disaster resilience in terms of investment decisions of affected businesses: 

-  Did you invest in repair and reconstruction?

-  Did you invest in the same location or an alternative location?

-  How much did you invest?

-  How much of your investment was to reduce or
vulnerability to future disasters 

3.  Formulation of a survey instrument to elicit responses on the four key metrics and related questions, such as the timing of investment and obstacles to its implementation. An additional attempt atobtaining a larger number of responses to the survey is planned for the coming months.

4.  A simulation of the macroeconomic aspects of dynamic economic resilience in the context of the 2008 Wenchuan Earthquake that identified the influence of various factors relating to Post-disaster investment in rebuilding the capital stock, such as amount and timing of insurance coverage and the amount and timing of government assistance.

5.  A reinterpretation of the standard definition of dynamic resilience that refers to the “speed of recovery.” We demonstrated that dynamic resilience and recovery were not the same thing. Moreover, we developed insight into the speed aspect of the definition by distinguishing between the time-path and overall duration of economic recovery.  We found that accelerating the time-path (jump-starting investment) is much more effective in reducing business interruption losses than reducing the duration of the recovery.  Moreover, this result generalizes to most typical recovery time-paths.
